called meow shoes for obvious reasons um they're actually very simple hardware
setup there are four pressure sensors there's one in the heel and the toe of each shoe and when you put them on um it
measures you know the pressure that you're putting on on each sensor and this hooks up to a companion app that I
made in a browser where via websockets it listens to these pressure hits and it
plays a 16b loop in the browser and whenever you sort of like are not standing and you just place your foot um
you know in a certain pattern you can cue up a musical note so you can essentially like use your feet to queue up music in the browser which is really
fun um probably the most fun part of this was figuring figuring out the algorithm for when people are just
standing still because otherwise you get all these insane sounds happening like all all at once so that was a really fun
project for me to kind of figure out this sort of stuff um this here is called the purr um
it's the personal ultimate reassurance response um this cat theme here and this has a heart rate sensor in
it and it's just a very chunky 3D printed um enclosure that I did and if it senses that you have an elevated

kittens um to try to try and chew you up so these are some of these are some of
the text messages that it sent um so it was a Wi-Fi enabled microcontroller that
can um like hit up the AT&T um API and AT&T is a big um
Telephone Company in um America so so it can hit that MMS API and then start dispatching kittens to you so that was

rather than like make lots of money um this was a hackathon project so it's

when you have an activity monitor the whole idea is you find your friends on the platform and you compete with each

Raspberry Pi Project so that it would um collect all of your activity at the end of every day and then it would come up

activity so it says quiet time and then it says around 5:00 I see there wasn't a

to sort of take that and push it more towards motivating other people to take
Delight in learning these things um but where does JavaScript fit into this
right um for a lot of those projects I did actually use JavaScript um in conjunction with you know Hardware
libraries and things like that um who actually writes JavaScript regularly
yeah we have a few okay I got the feeling that most of the audience here is like Java and Android and stuff so
yesterday I talked to a lot of folks and I was like hm so you're probably
asking why JavaScript like why would you use JavaScript to do Hardware because normally you would use C or lure or just
you know something that's not a web browser language um and so you know I sort of want to um you know tell you why
I personally think that it's really really um beneficial so I see JavaScript as this universal language um and that's
because it's kind of escaped and leaked out of the browser in the last few years and so you can run it um as nodejs um
there are lots of different JavaScript engines now and you know even Microsoft open source their Shakra um engine and
so you can pretty much run it any way you like and so that makes it incredibly flexible um and it is it is performant
to the point where you can be managing streams of data coming in from devices um it has a low barrier to entry a lot
of people going through um Dev boot camps and things like that um there's a lot of Dev boot camps in New York for
example they're coming in and learning HTML CSS and JavaScript and it's amazing that they can learn um those languages
in a specific context but then they can take those skills and apply them elsewhere and I think that's really
really really powerful and I think that given that so many people are learning JavaScript we should be letting
JavaScript shine and and you know giving people the opportunity to do more with it um it's very it's a very event driven
language um I think it was Chris's talk yesterday he was talking about how lure
um The Lure library for the ESP 8266 tried to sort of emulate that event driven kind of thing so that it means
that JavaScript got something right when it comes to Hardware if you're listening for sensor data or if you're trying to
trigger things to happen on a device like having a language that's you know like where events are just natively part
of it and asynchronous things are natively part of the language I think that's really powerful um and lastly
it's called The Internet of Things and JavaScript is you know works in the browser and it was kind of written for
internet e things so I just think it makes a lot of sense as a pairing in
general so I was doing a lot of these projects by myself and you know I was
kind of cobbling together all of these JavaScript things like node serial port and web sockets and things like that
just like trying to get it all together and then in 2013 I ran into the nodebots

and people have written a lot of things that I haven't bothered to to make the experience a lot nicer and I got so
inspired by that that I kind of jumped in and and wanted to kind of be part of
this so a friend uh a friend and I recently um when I lived in Las Vegas
which is another story by itself um I was living in Las Vegas at the time and I came back just couldn't stop talking
about this noots movement and so we both both decided to um run like a noteb day
or a a workshop in Las Vegas to teach people like you know the gospel of JavaScript robotics um and there's

Shopper where there's lots of different flavors of it where it's a terminal app and it takes you through teaching you things step by step so we sort of looked
at a bunch of these things and we thought we can do this like we can we can run this so this this is a picture I
think of the first nodebots day um that was run in 2014 in Las Vegas and it was
run in this like like super nap kind of place with this amazing internet so it
was really really exciting it was like a giant data center um and we had kids and we had adults and um we just had all
sorts of people wanting to learn how to do this and it was a raging success of a day and it was so exciting to see the
the um the things that people made um and then we ended up battling the bot at the end of the day after they learned
how to put them together so you can kind of see that over the lunch break people took Cutlery from the
lunch and and drinking cups and put them on the devices which is really really
cool someone made a sponsor bot where they just took all the sponsor stickers and stuck them all over the bot which I thought was awesome um you can tell
which one is mine it's the cat on the left at the front um so that was really cool and I
was addicted and I thought how can I give back to this community more because because um I for for the first time you
know I found myself inspired by the fact that um yeah I just didn't have to do the stuff alone so that's when I moved
into making tools instead of projects and then hopefully those tools will help other people create projects and then
hopefully we'll see a ripple effect there um and obviously I'm only one person within this nodebots community um

awesome um so the first library that I wrote um for JavaScript Hardware was
called OJs so this is an OLED screen uh if anyone's got a Fitbit this is pretty

um and I thought these things were really cool but I noticed that in the Johnny 5 JavaScript Hardware Library um
it has so many different um like modules available for all the different pieces of Hardware but they didn't have one for
an OED screen so I ended up um downloading the the data sheet for this
device and then I kind of reverse engineered a bunch of code and stuff to figure out how to write this in JavaScript um and that and as you can
see I've put a cat on there because that's the theme and I found this so rewarding and
I learned so much from it that I kind of got addicted so I've now kind of been on
this road to how can I figure out how to take down as many barriers as possible for people so a project that I'll be
talking about in in most of my case studies today will be around the um
project AVR girl has anyone heard of AVR girl a couple yeah because you did your

dude is a c-based um executable that allows you to flash um code to any AVR
um you know chip made by atmail and that that includes arduinos so if you're if
you've ever used the Arduino ID before and you click the upload button um that's actually using AVR dude under the
surface so I wanted to bring that into um you know the 21st century and write
rewrite it in JavaScript um so that it would have unit testing and it would have an active um community and probably
a slightly more inclusive community who you know weren't burnt out from managing this um AVR dude is like a at least a
16-year-old app now and the community is a little fragmented they're a little bit like the old guard and I just didn't
have a great relationship with them so I sort of took my ball and went home but like I wanted to bring this into the
JavaScript community so I'll talk about a few details on the things that I tried to do to lower the barriers to people
using um even just this Library so case study one out of the box
experience now you all know when you create because you create products every day that the the outof thebox experience
is one of the most important experiences that you can spend time on it's the first impression that someone has with
your uh your tool or your product right and so it's really important to get that right um and when you're learning how to
interface with an Arduino for the first time that's you know you're out of the box experience it can be really
confusing you're like I have this thing that's kind of a different computer but I have to plug it into my computer and I
don't really know how that's happening and I already feel really intimidated so like who felt intimidated when they
first kind of pulled an Arduino out of the box and they're like now what yeah a few I felt like that too um and in
JavaScript Hardware this is actually what's going on under the surface there's a lot of different tools um there's Johnny 5 on the left the
crocodile is my interpretation of um form JS um I have a talk that I did on
this that I can send out afterwards um it's using node serial port to send you know the data over and then you know on
the board itself there's also the formata sketch and it's talking with all of the cat Butlers that are fiddling
with the pin on the device and so there's a lot going on but you don't necessarily have to expose people to
that on day one but we found that a lot of people were being kind of exposed to
this stuff just because we didn't have a better way of abstracting it away um so
the the previous flow to getting started with JavaScript robotics was download the Arduino ID and everyone's like okay
um I like using Sublime Text but it's it's fine um and they have to install it and then they open the ID and they're
just like what is this Java thing I'm not sure what it is uh we direct them to open the standard formata sketch um and
for those who who um AR privy to formata formata is a protocol um that you can
Flash as code onto an Arduino and it essentially exposes um all of the pins
and all of the functionality as an API so if you send the correct bites down the the chain then the um standard forat
script knows your intent and can perform actions for you so you can pretty much communicate with an Arduino uh tethered
via USB or Wi-Fi which is really awesome so we use that for people to be able to run JavaScript locally to kind of remote
control their arduinos when they're first getting started so they open the standard for M sketch it doesn't that
doesn't even sound like English to them um they then have to kind of go through the menus and pick the correct Arduino
board on the correct USB port they have plugged in then they click this tiny little tick button which will upload the
code um and then they're not done yet they close the ID and then they never open it again and it's just sitting
around as 150 Megs on their hard drive because they're too scared to delete it um and then they feel really confused
and then we're like okay now we're doing JavaScript and they're like oh I guess I've got to npm install some stuff now
and you know it just keeps going so I particularly felt that this was not
a great experience and I complained about it for a really long time and no one really seemed that engaged with
solving it and I was just like it shouldn't be like this and people like yeah it shouldn't um but that's not
super helpful and I'm pretty sure that I complained about this for at least six months before I did something about it so just kept saying we can do better we
can do better and then um someone who I look up to in the industry a lot she looked me in the eye and she's like well
you could do that like and I was like no I'm not capable she's like no you could um so it was almost like a dare so um I
wrote AVR girl so that you had a way to npm install something to just upload
code and so then you can include it in setup scripts and the user doesn't even have to know about it so if you can npm
install something that's less than 17 Megs worth of dependencies then that's something that JavaScript people
understand pretty well they're like yeah I know how to npm install something um so that's already a better experience
and then if we're doing all of this nice standard formata stuff for them without them realizing then again that's an easy
way to get people into um you know getting started and then they can go back and learn that stuff later on once
they're a little bit more confident so uh AV go Arduino works as both a
programmatic include or import into your code or you can use it on the command line it's really up to you on how you
install it so you run the command uh so I have different flavors of AVR girl this is the Arduino one so you run AVR
girl Arduino um you tell it to flash um you tell it which board and which file that's pretty much it and you can use
like- V for verose like debug output um and this this you know works pretty much
in the same way that AVR dude does but you know under the surface we have some nicer built-ins for for JavaScript
people so that's a brief overview of how that works I was then able to take AVR
girl and Abstract that another layer and I created a um mpm module called fata
party um and I was trying to make it all Jolly and I was like yeah we're going to do robots so we're going to have a formata party just for like 5 minutes
where we're going to upload formata to our device so you can essentially um mpm install that you run for M party and
then what Arduino you use so in this case it would be um an Arduino Uno and a
friend of mine actually poor requested me recently um Francis wanted party mode
so if you run it in party mode you can just plug arduinos in press any key and it'll Flash and then you disconnect and

boards have the code installed so I loved the fact that there was a party mode which is pretty cool so yeah I feel
like he really got um the idea of this so that was really nice to see that resonate so you know we got this really

get clone a directory and then they run that and then again like they're just writing JavaScript immediately which is

out there that are willing to write the tools for you to do that and you are also very capable of writing these tools too um if if just important enough to
you so that makes people a lot happier and it's really exciting to see you know
them not feel so intimidated all the time so case study two when things go
wrong because they will um so you know this is an example

like well why couldn't it find it um and so people open issues and they're like
hey it's not working with my Arduino um and for those who have maintained open

great um and at the same time testing writing unit tests and mocking out
Hardware it can be really useful but what you really need when you write this stuff is real testers um with real

and if it works cool if it doesn't let me know and no one was doing that right like no one was like yeah that sounds
like fun no one really likes testing and no one really likes manually testing um although I'm very excited for your talk
because to be honest I love testing but I just know that most people don't um so I thought well what I'm actually asking
the users and the consumers of my tool to do is a lot I'm asking for them a lot and I'm I'm taking their time for
granted and I'm taking their generosity for granted so I thought what can I do um so I was like let's make helping fun
again so I tried to figure out a useful abstraction where people can have
something that's reproducible that um you know follows a script every time and it really helps me
and they don't necessarily have to get in contact with me to um to help out so I thought that that would be useful so I

pops up this surprise browser window um and it asks you to follow a bunch of
steps for me and so you plug in your Arduino you tell it what board it is so there's no command line mumbo jumbo and
then you just click Start the test and what it essentially does is it it helps you um it just flashes a um a script to

road I'll explain why but you can log in with GitHub 2 so that I know like that you were awesome and you tested for me
so this is an example of you know one of the tests failing where we have an error right down the bottom and it says no
uino Uno found but I'm showing the user that okay this is the information I'm
going to send you know because privacy is really important so um there's the username the board that were using the
operating system that were using the version of AVR girl that we using the version of the test pilot software that
we're using um and whether there were any errors and um you can't see it's
slightly off the screen but you can tick an anonymous box so that I don't send your username but if you do send your

incentive um so then that just beams up to my catch DB database and you know I
get to look at these really interesting eras and I get to kind of see the collisions of all the different versions of everything and the versions of node
and and all sorts of stuff so that really helps me because I'm not always going to be on top of all of the

worried about so cool so case study three the useful feedback loop so
Everyone likes a really tight feedback loop when they're developing right it's it's super important because you don't
want to waste time waiting for builds and stuff but you also want to have really useful debugging behavior um so
AV girl has nine types of Errors so there are nine different things that that can go wrong um it's everything
from it couldn't find the board to uh it lost connection with the board halfway through like executing um something or
writing the the script on um there's all these different protocol eras of the communication protocols I'm using under
the surface there's also just trying to think oh there's also just oh you didn't
um that's not even a valid board you know that you supplied and things like that so reporting these errors and are
really um easy to kind of like understand way can be quite cumbersome because these are the
different error types that you get with JavaScript right you have an eval error an internal a range error a reference
error a syntax error type and URI I feel like there's no Hardware specific errors
in this I know that Java has like way better exceptions I was like geeking out about that last night and researching it but this is sort of all you have to work
with and if you don't set um your error to be one of these types what you get is kind of not a
great experience you just get a normal error so it becomes a generic error so imagine that you're using AVR girl um
with your autonomous sailboat for example which actually did happen um at one point someone was using AVR girl
uino to update over the air an autonomous sailboat that was sailing across the Atlantic which was amazing
they contributed back with some PRS it was great um imagine that you're like okay so an error happened but I have no
idea what the error was and like what what can you do like you can you just reject the string that I'm returning
that's in English like that's just not a nice experience and JavaScript is just really not equipped to handle that kind
of thing so it would be nice if the error name was like board not found error and it was something that was
constant and something that was easily interpret uh interpreted by a machine and a human so that you can actually
provide the user with like some kind of feedback as to like oh try replugging your board again because they're not
going to know what Uno not found you know means it's it's still a little bit kind of abstract to them so you can you
can maybe use the message if you want but you can also have the opportunity to write your own and then you know exactly what happened too so um in JavaScript
you can actually just um use composability to like build upon the the
error um object that you have available to you so you can create a new one and then you can kind of add in extra fields
and things on top of it so that's something that I experimented with recently um Mark mentioned that I do
this twitch stream Where I Live code and then I put it on YouTube later so I do have one called nicer errors that you
can watch if you go to my YouTube channel it's a very unflattering video still but I couldn't find a better one
um so what's the advantage in creating you know these kind of error abstractions well part of it is it's
internationalization friendly so people can create their own error messages in their own language
